work.p: This manuscript is similar in subject to the following line from the poem eventually titled "I Sing the Body Electric": "Was it dreamed whether those who corrupted their own live bodies could conceal themselves?" (1855, p. 77)

notesStmt.note: On the back of this leaf, Whitman drafted trial lines of the poem that was eventually titled "Song of Myself." Based on this and the handwriting, Edward Grier dates this manuscript to before or early in 1855 (Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts [New York: New York University Press, 1984], 1:179).

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: tainting the best of the rich orchard...
bibl.orgName: The Oscar Lion Papers, 1914–1955, New York Public Library, New York, N.Y.
bibl.note: Transcribed from our own digital image of orginal manuscript.
This manuscript is glued to another manuscript that also features lines of prose. On the back of the leaf are draft lines of poetry.

revisionDesc.change: checked; revised repository information in header

body.ab: tainting the best of the rich orchard of himself . . . . and he who anyway does not respect his own organs and cherish them and strengthen them, and keep himself clean not only on his face but outside and inside—need not let that man young or old never de deceive himself with the folly that the bad sore stuff and the under is hid by the cloth he wears and his makes no avowal.—Though the secret is well hid, though the eye does not see, nor the hand touch, nor the nose smell, the rank odor strikes out
